item.title: At $236 Million, Klimt Piece Is Second Most Expensive Painting Sold at Auction
item.description: At $236.4 million, a portrait by Gustav Klimt is the second most expensive painting at auction, while Maurizio Cattelan’s golden toilet drew $12.1 million.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small and Julia Halperin
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: Modern art history: The auctioneer at Sotheby’s, Oliver Barker, hammered down a final bid on a portrait of Elisabeth Lederer by Klimt.

item.title: Body Slams, Curated: Pro Wrestling Enters Its Museum Era
item.description: The over-the-top spectacle has been slicing into the art world, with gallery shows, performances and a forthcoming major exhibition.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik and Marcus Maddox
item.category: Pioneer Works Center for Art and Innovation (Brooklyn, NY)
item.media:credit: Marcus Maddox for The New York Times

item.title: How Much Sex, Drugs and Violence Can Be in a PG-13 Movie?
item.description: The movie ratings board has pulled back the curtain on how it approaches hot-button topics, including nudity, marijuana and guns.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs

item.title: A.I. Video Is Threatening Our Ability to Trust Documentaries
item.description: A combination of technological developments and market forces is undermining the trust between viewer and filmmaker. What’s at stake is history itself.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Roadrunner: A Film About Anthony Bourdain (Movie)
The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst (TV Program)

item.title: In This Show, Four Years of High School Unfold Over Five Hours
item.description: The characters in Else Went’s quiet Off Broadway debut at the Public Theater try to make sense of the world while coming-of-age in the early aughts.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Corzine

item.title: Daniele Rustioni, Old-School Conductor, Joins the Met Opera
item.description: Daniele Rustioni is already busy as the Met’s new principal guest conductor, with three shows onstage this fall.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.media:credit: Elias Williams for The New York Times

item.title: George Benjamin and Pierre-Laurent Aimard: Friendship in Music
item.description: The composer George Benjamin and the pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard met as students. In a new piece, they perform at the keyboard together.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.media:credit: Jared Soares for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pierre-Laurent Aimard, left, and George Benjamin.

item.title: On ‘Finally Over It,’ Summer Walker Is R&B’s Maestro of the Funny Side of Heartbreak
item.description: On “Finally Over It,” the singer and songwriter rolls her eyes and brings in like-minded cynics for tracks that recall the soulful sounds of the ’90s.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica
item.media:credit: Scott Legato/Getty Images
item.media:description: On Summer Walker’s most powerful songs, she sings in a manner so offhand, it’s as if she forgot it was a song altogether rather than a bemused berating.

item.title: ‘Meet the Cartozians’ Review: Who Gets to Be White in America?
item.description: Talene Monahon’s captivating play uses a 1925 court decision to explore what identity means to Armenians here (a certain reality TV star included).
item.dc:creator: Juan A. Ramírez
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: The cast of “Meet the Cartozians,” from left: Will Brill, Tamara Sevunts, Andrea Martin, Raffi Barsoumian and Nael Nacer at the Pershing Square Signature Center in Manhattan.

item.title: ‘25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee’ Review: A Delightful Competition
item.description: Adult actors play fierce middle-school spellers in a wonderful revival of William Finn and Rachel Sheinkin’s musical.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.category: The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee (Play)
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: From left: Jasmine Amy Rodgers, Leana Rae Concepcion, Autumn Best, Justin Cooley, Philippe Arroyo and Kevin McHale in “The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee” at New World Stages in Manhattan.

item.title: ‘Lahppon/Lost’ Was a Hit in Oslo. But in the Sami Heartland?
item.description: The Norwegian National Ballet was nervous about taking a new work about a Sami uprising to the area where the historical event took place.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Abend and David B. Torch
item.media:credit: David B. Torch for The New York Times

item.title: Obsessed With ‘Wicked’? Try 9 More Songs From Beloved Musicals.
item.description: If you’ve got Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande on repeat, add these songs from “Rent,” “Hadestown,” “13” and more to the rotation.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Coleman

item.title: Met Museum Employees Petition to Create Union
item.description: The proposal, for a union to represent nearly 1,000 employees, would make the Met one of the largest unionized museums in the country.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at the Metropolitan Museum of Art are petitioning to form a union.

item.title: Met Returns Buddhist Painting Thought Taken During the Korean War
item.description: The 18th-century painting, which the Met acquired in 2007, is believed to have been removed from a South Korean temple while it was controlled by the U.S. Army.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.category: Los Angeles County Museum of Art
item.media:credit: The Met Museum
item.media:description: The painting, “The Tenth King of Hell,” is one of ten scrolls that were removed from Sinheungsa Temple in northeastern South Korea.

item.title: Stephen Colbert Celebrates ‘Epstein Rockin’ Eve’
item.description: “Stay up for a ball drop you’re going to want to miss,” the “Late Show” host said as Congress voted for the release of the Jeffrey Epstein files.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)

item.title: ‘This World of Tomorrow’ Review: Tom Hanks Is Back in Town
item.description: The movie star plays a man from the future at the 1939 New York World’s Fair in an adaptation of some of his stories. Kelli O’Hara shines as his love interest.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Hanks, Kayli Carter and Kelli O’Hara in “This World of Tomorrow” at the Shed in Manhattan.

item.title: Artists Pick Their Favorite Films About Artists
item.description: Movies with artist-protagonists are known to be disappointing. These pass muster and even inspire.
item.dc:creator: Julia Halperin

item.title: ‘Selena y Los Dinos’ Review: Still Dreaming of You
item.description: In this look back at the singer Selena, the director Isabel Castro presents home video footage and photographs that have not been seen in other documentaries.
item.dc:creator: Chris Azzopardi

item.title: Vanity Fair’s New Hollywood Issue, First Under New Editor, Is All About Men
item.description: Mark Guiducci gave his first issue of Vanity Fair over to the guys.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher

item.title: The Art of Britain’s Windrush Generation Has Never Felt More Relevant
item.description: At a time of rising xenophobia and nativism, their work examines the meeting of different cultures, and their own right to belong.
item.dc:creator: Aatish Taseer

item.title: New to Cyberpunk Books? Here’s Where to Start.
item.description: The science fiction writer Chloe Gong recommends new and classic books that push the boundaries of the genre, with plenty of techno thrills.
item.dc:creator: Chloe Gong
item.media:credit: Author photo by One Grid Studio

item.title: Late Night Is Amused by Trump’s About-Face on the Epstein Files
item.description: “We have nothing to hide,” President Trump said about releasing the documents. Jimmy Kimmel shot back: “I have some bad news: There’s no ‘we.’ It’s just you, bro.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)
Last Week Tonight With John Oliver (TV Program)

item.title: Bill Ivey, 81, Dies; Quelled Conservative Ire Over U.S. Arts Agency
item.description: As the head of the National Endowment for the Arts, Mr. Ivey, a leader in country music, shifted the agency’s focus away from avant-garde work and won more funding.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum
item.media:credit: Susana Raab for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Ivey, then the outgoing chairman, in his office at the National Endowment for the Arts in Washington in 2001. He changed the agency’s image by, among other things, distributing grants to projects in 20 states where federal arts money was rarely spent.

item.title: Review: ‘The Monkey King’ Premieres at San Francisco Opera
item.description: Huang Ruo and David Henry Hwang’s “The Monkey King,” based on “Journey to the West,” brings an old superhero to the opera stage.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone

item.title: With New Condé M. Nast Galleries, the Met Museum Gets Fashion Forward
item.description: The Costume Institute is bringing its annual blockbuster show to a permanent home off the Grand Hall, thanks to Anna Wintour’s efforts to get “out of the basement.”
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin and Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Jonah Rosenberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Metropolitan Museum will name a new ground-floor gallery for the American publishing entrepreneur Condé Nast and feature its blockbuster Costume Institute show right off the Great Hall.

item.title: Tom Cruise Accepts an Honorary Oscar at the Governors Awards
item.description: The star was feted along with Debbie Allen, Dolly Parton and the production designer Wynn Thomas at a show that has become an awards campaign stop.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images
item.media:description: Tom Cruise with his trophy for the evening.

item.title: A Day at the Beach Hunting Mammoths
item.description: “Citizen paleontologists” can keep the fossils they uncover around Europe’s largest port. All the professionals ask is that those amateurs let them know.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal and Ilvy Njiokiktjien
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times

item.title: These Six Artworks Could Predict the Auction Market
item.description: The art market had a summer of closures and consolidations. But major collections, blue-chip art and guarantees have pushed expectations high for the marquee sales.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small, Julia Halperin and Tim F. Schneider
item.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times
item.media:description: A viewer crouches next to Maurizio Cattelan’s artwork-as-loo.

item.title: Has This Director Made the Year’s Most Terrifying Movie?
item.description: With the existential action thriller “Sirat,” set in the rave culture of Morocco, Oliver Laxe says that he was not out to shock, but that he is still haunted by one scene.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg
item.media:credit: Maxime La for The New York Times
item.media:description: The question isn’t why someone dies, said Oliver Laxe, director of “Sirat.” “It’s, How do you die?” he said, adding, “Can you imagine your death dancing?”

item.title: A Fats Waller Musical All but Disappeared (Until Now)
item.description: The jazz pianist and composer wrote music for the World War II hit “Early to Bed,” which was running when he died at 39. Two concerts will bring its songs back to life.
item.dc:creator: Will Friedwald
item.media:credit: Bettmann/Getty Images
item.media:description: Fats Waller was originally intended to perform in “Early to Bed,” but his role went to another musician.

item.title: Broadway’s Radical ‘Oedipus,’ With Mark Strong and Lesley Manville
item.description: Icke dusts off the classics the way a restorer brightens an old master painting. His latest project stars Mark Strong and Lesley Manville.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone
item.media:credit: Ye Fan for The New York Times
item.media:description: The actors Mark Strong, left, and Lesley Manville with the writer and director Robert Icke.

item.title: What Should I Do With My Playbill?
item.description: Readers ask about the most environmentally friendly thing to do with an unwanted program. And by the way, why is it always yellow?
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson

item.title: Those Little Chimes That Say ‘Please Take Your Seat’
item.description: At New York’s performing arts venues, herding audiences is a melodic mission.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi and Vincent Alban

item.title: Ballet Dancers Are Starting to Prioritize Their Mental Health
item.description: Dancers are famous for buckling down and getting through it. But a new openness about mental health has companies and schools focusing on their well-being, both physical and emotional.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas and Thea Traff
item.media:description: Sara Mearns of New York City Ballet has been frank on social media about her mental health struggles.

item.title: A BravoCon Recap, Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: Catch up on everything that happened in Vegas, and get ready for the CMAs.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:credit: Charles Sykes/Bravo
item.media:description: Andy Cohen at BravoCon in 2023.

item.title: ‘Chess,’ With Lea Michele: At Least They Have the Abba Songs
item.description: This new revival, starring Lea Michele, Nicholas Christopher and Aaron Tveit, is a reminder why the erratic yet rewarding show has endured all these years.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli and Sara Krulwich
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times

item.title: ‘It: Welcome to Derry’ Season 1, Episode 4 Recap: Origin of the Species
item.description: Leroy gets a glimpse of the thing that terrorized his son. Viewers get a glimpse of the monster’s origins in Derry.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:credit: Brooke Palmer/HBO
item.media:description: Leroy (Jovan Adepo) rescued Will (Blake Cameron James) from an attack while they were fishing. The scratches on Will’s arms were too real to ignore.

item.title: Homayoun Ershadi, 78, Dies; ‘Kite Runner’ and ‘Taste of Cherry’ Star
item.description: He was an architect with no training as an actor whose life was changed by a chance encounter. He inspired rave reviews and a New Yorker short story.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub

item.title: Epstein Files Dominate “S.N.L.,” With the Help of Will Forte’s MacGruber
item.description: The Epstein files played a prominent role in this episode hosted by Glen Powell, while Will Forte returned to play his fan-favorite character MacGruber.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff

item.title: ‘Now You See Me: Now You Don’t’ Has Tricks Up Its Sleeve
item.description: The magician heist thriller franchise is back for a third installment. We go beyond the illusion to find out why these movies endure.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.category: Now You See Me: Now You Don't (Movie)

item.title: Leslie Odom Jr., Back in the Room Where It Happens
item.description: In “Hamilton,” no moment captures the actor’s emotional expansiveness, artistic breadth and vocal depth better than this number.
item.dc:creator: Salamishah Tillet
item.media:credit: Elias Williams for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Ten years ago, the performance was powered by rage,” said Leslie Odom Jr., whose limited run in “Hamilton” has brought a high demand for tickets. “I’m powered by love now.”

item.title: Todd Snider, Folk Singer With a Wry Wit, Dies at 59
item.description: Mentored by the likes of Jimmy Buffett and John Prine, his big-hearted ballads told of heartache even as his humor revealed a steadfast optimism.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: The folk singer Todd Snider in New York in 2009.

item.title: SAG Awards Changes Its Name to the Actor Awards
item.description: The annual awards, started three decades ago by the Hollywood union SAG-AFTRA, has begun to reach a global audience through livestreaming on Netflix.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Chris Pizzello/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The change will align the show’s name with the name of the statuette that winners receive, which has long been known as the Actor.

item.title: Lupita Nyong’o in ‘Twelfth Night,’ and More Theater to Stream
item.description: This month’s picks include a ravishing Nyong’o in the return of Shakespeare in the Park, and an audio play starring Liev Schreiber and Maggie Siff.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli
item.media:credit: Richard Termine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lupita Nyong’o, right, with Joe Tapper in “Twelfth Night” at the Delacorte Theater in Manhattan this summer.

item.title: For ‘The Running Man,’ Colman Domingo Is Your Host
item.description: While the Emmy-winning, Oscar-nominated actor loves to put on a show, his role as Bobby T in this Stephen King adaptation is the first time he has played a showman in the movies.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg and Jason Nocito
item.media:credit: Jason Nocito for The New York Times

item.title: At the Broadway Flea, a Market for Props, Playbills and a Good Cause
item.description: Theater lovers came in search of souvenirs at the Broadway Flea Market & Grand Auction this fall, all for a good cause.
item.dc:creator: Vidhya Nagarajan and Sarah Bahr

item.title: ‘Nouvelle Vague’: All the References Explained
item.description: The Netflix film about the making of Jean-Luc Godard’s French New Wave classic “Breathless” is chock-full of names with key roles in cinema history.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: Niecy Nash-Betts Saves It for the ‘All’s Fair’ Group Chat
item.description: “It’ll make you laugh, it’ll give you support, it’ll give you the tea, because sometimes you got to spill it,” the actress said.
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Shattuck
item.media:credit: Emma Mcintyre/Getty Images for Critics Choice

item.title: Fired Scholars and Big Grants to Favored Projects: Inside Trump’s N.E.H.
item.description: Some Democrats and supporters of the National Endowment for the Humanities are questioning what they see as gutted procedures and a tilt toward handpicked projects.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: The headquarters of the National Endowment for the Humanities in Washington, where the Trump administration has slashed grant programs and the number of staff members.

item.title: The Kids Are Up All Night, With Jewels and Bones
item.description: After a five-year hiatus, the much-loved tradition of sleepovers at the American Museum of Natural History has returned.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski and Lucia Bell-Epstein
item.media:credit: Lucia Bell-Epstein for The New York Times
item.media:description: and something about the kid in the dinosaur mask.

item.title: NBA YoungBoy, Rap’s Defining 2025 Superstar, Is Hiding in Plain Sight
item.description: Following three years of house arrest and a pardon from President Trump, the Baton Rouge, La., rapper recently completed one of the biggest tours in rap history.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica and Graham Dickie
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times

item.title: “Convent Wisdom” Looks to Nuns from Yesterday to Help Make It Through Today
item.description: The unlikely collaboration of two academics, “Convent Wisdom” provides unholy guidance by intertwining religious history with popular culture.
item.dc:creator: María Sánchez Díez

item.title: Yvonne Brewster, Godmother of Black British Theater, Dies at 87
item.description: When she studied acting in London in the 1950s, she was told she was unlikely to find work. She ended up starting one of the country’s foremost Black theaters.
item.dc:creator: Stella Raine Chu

item.title: Elizabeth Franz, Versatile Tony-Winning Actress, Is Dead at 84
item.description: She won the award for her performance as Linda Loman in a 1999 Broadway revival of “Death of a Salesman” and played the matriarch Kate Jerome in two Neil Simon comedies.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All for You (Play)

item.title: Want to Buy a Work of Art at Auction? Here’s What to Know.
item.description: A step-by-step guide to navigating this oft-misunderstood part of the market, with tips on getting what you want without experiencing buyer’s remorse.
item.dc:creator: Julia Halperin

item.title: ‘The Seat of Our Pants’ Review: Songs for the World’s End
item.description: Ruthie Ann Miles, Shuler Hensley and Micaela Diamond lead a dream-team cast in Ethan Lipton’s musical adaptation of Thornton Wilder’s “The Skin of Our Teeth.”
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: Micaela Diamond, standing, as Sabina and Ruthie Ann Miles as Mrs. Antrobus in the musical “The Seat of Our Pants” at the Public Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: Paris Opera’s Youth Orchestra Program Starts With Young Talent
item.description: A youth orchestra program for musicians as young as 8 is part of Paris Opera’s effort to widen access to the art form and secure its future.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Schmid

item.title: Paris Opera Debuts ‘Satyagraha’ by Philip Glass, Directed by Dancers
item.description: The choreographers Bobbi Jene Smith and Or Schraiber will put their own spin on “Satyagraha” by Philip Glass for its Paris Opera premiere.
item.dc:creator: David Belcher
item.media:credit: Erik Tanner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smith and Schraiber pose for a portrait. “The process of digging and making movement is a big part of our daily process, whether these things end up in the piece or not,” Schraiber said of their development process.

item.title: Maxime Pascal to Conduct Stockhausen’s ‘Montag aus Licht’ in Paris
item.description: For one night only at the Philharmonie de Paris, Maxime Pascale will conduct “Montag aus Licht,” part of his bid to stage a septology long deemed unperformable.
item.dc:creator: A.J. Goldmann

item.title: Discovering 5 Treasures of Photography
item.description: Some of the most impressive photographs on display at the Paris Photo Fair were made many decades ago but are now being seen anew or, in some cases, for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Emily LaBarge

item.title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
item.description: In this month’s picks, parents and children in India, Germany, Korea, Italy and Sudan grapple with the joys and perils of familial bonds.
item.dc:creator: Devika Girish

item.title: Eddie Murphy Addresses ‘S.N.L.’ Feud in “Being Eddie” Documentary
item.description: The comedian’s long-running feud with the late-night sketch show is a topic in the new Netflix documentary “Being Eddie.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams

item.title: ‘Now I’m on the Stage’: 7 Artists on Their Museum Residencies in Harlem
item.description: The Studio Museum in Harlem’s longtime residency program has been pivotal to artists of color. Here, alumni look back on why it was so crucial.
item.dc:creator: Seph Rodney
